name: Eastern Kiang
description: It has light rusty to brown fur, with a white belly, legs, and front of the neck. A dark stripe runs down the middle of its back, and its short, upright mane is dark.
spread_note: Tibetan Plateau at elevations of 2,700–5,400 m – China, also Pakistan, India, Nepal, and possibly Bhutan; the eastern kiang occurs in the Chinese provinces of Qinghai and southwestern Xinjiang.
proportions: Body length 2.1 m; tail length 40 cm; shoulder height 1.3–1.5 m; weight 250–400 kg
attractions: The rugged Central Asian steppes are home to several wild ass species, including the kiang. Its habitat is the Tibetan highlands, where temperatures drop below -40°C in winter at around 4,000 m elevation. Herds consist primarily of females and young. Stallions are territorial, guarding the mares in their domain. Young males often form bachelor groups until they establish their own territories. A newborn kiang can follow its mother within an hour and stays close to her in the early days. Kiangs have three subspecies, with the eastern kiang being the largest.
breeding: One kiang stallion lived at the zoo from 1961–1971. After a 20-year break, breeding resumed in 1991.
